   OLYMPICS

   IOC-FINANCES _ LONDON _ Before the 1992 Barcelona Games, the
International Olympic commitee listed assets of nearly $100 million
-- that was before the most lucrative period in the IOC's history.
But seven years later, the committee is now estimated to have more
than $200 million in assets. Where does the IOC hoarde its cash and
does this do much for the image of world amateur sports?
Developing. (Roughton, Cox News Service).

   WITH

   IOC-DATA _ LONDON _ Financial data on the IOC's assets.
(Roughton, Cox News Service).

   EDs: MOVED in the (i) International and (s) Sports categories.

   INTERNATIONAL

   MEXICO-BARTLETT _ PUEBLA, Mexico _ Among the many books in the
governor's mansion here, Manuel Bartlett kept a copy of ``The
Illustrated Encyclopedia of Dinosaurs.'' It was an amusing choice
of reading for a man now struggling to overcome an image as one of
Mexico's own most endangered species. Bartlett -- who wants to be
Mexico's next president -- is one of this country's ``dinosaurs,''
the not-so-affectionate nickname for the old, authoritarian guard
of the Revolutionary Institutional Party, or PRI, which has
controlled Mexico's presidency for 70 years. A career politician
and recent governor of Puebla state, Bartlett represents the past
to Mexicans who believe he engineered old-fashioned electoral fraud
and other anti-democratic evils. But this shrewd politician claims
he's the PRI's best bet to hang onto the presidency in July 2000,
when Mexicans go to the polls in the most competitive presidential
election in Mexican history. (Ferriss, Cox News Service). WITH
PHOTO

   WITH

   BARTLETT-BOX _ MEXICO CITY _ A biobox on Manual Bartlett.
(Ferriss, Cox News Service)

   EDs: Box MOVED Wed., March 10. Story MOVED Thurs., March 11.

   KOSOVO-GIRL _ Teen-age reporter for Youth Radio in the San
Francisco Bay area, has been conducting an electronic
coorespondence with a teen-age Albanian girl named Adona, who is
living a harrowing, precarious life in the war-ravaged province of
Kosovo. She is surrounded by a war-zone, where rival Serbian and
Albanian militias are killing each other and massacring civilians
for control of this parcel of the former Yugoslavia. Her story has
become familiar to listeners of NPR. (Browning, Palm Beach Post)
MOVED

   PALM BEACH SMUGGLING SERIES

   EDs: The Palm Beach Post has a three-day package for Saturday,
March 13, Sunday, March 14, and Monday, March 15, on the business
of smuggling aliens; why the U.S. Border Patrol, the INS and the
federal court system cope poorly with it in Florida; and why
Florida employers are able to hire hundreds of thousands of illegal
workers each year. Here are the budget lines for the second day in
the series. STORIES HAVE MOVED. FOUR PHOTOS AND FOUR GRAPHICS ARE
AVAILABLE.

   SMUGGLE-MAIN _ WEST PALM, BEACH, Fla. _ Smuggling immigrants
into Florida is a money-making enterprise. It's becoming a booming
business as more and more immigrants find that paying smugglers
equipped with fast boats and high-tech gear improves their chances
of reaching the United States. Sometimes it goes wrong, as when 40
Haitians drowned between the Bahamas and Palm Beach County last
weekend. The Border Patrol is charged with the responsibility of
putting the alien smuggler out of business. But the Miami sector
has less than 60 agents to patrol its four-state region. The agency
hasn't seen an increase in its workforce in 10 years. During that
period, the U.S. Border Patrol has experienced dramatic growth,
doubling the number of agents to a force of nearly 8,000.
Unfortunately for the Miami sector, almost all of the thousands of
agents hired during the past few years have been assigned to Texas,
California, New Mexico and Arizona. For example: The Miami Sector
has 52 agents assigned; Laredo (Texas) has 638; El Paso has 9,752;
Tucson has 1,022; and San Diego has 2,257. Miami's budget is $6.2
million; San Diego is $178 million. (Kane, Palm Beach Post) 60
inches.

   SMUGGLE-NIGHT _ Border Patrol Agent Larry Belotti works the
graveyard shift. He says he's the often the only Border Patrol
agent working from Corpus Christi, Texas, to Vermont. One recent
night, he rounded up 26 Cubans who came ashore in Miami Beach. This
effectively shuts down the Border Patrol station because Belotti
will spend the rest of the night processing these refugees. 30
inches. (Kane, Palm Beach Post)

   SMUGGLE-PUNISH _ U.S. Attorney Tom Scott says his office is
adopting an aggressive stand against alien smugglers. These cases
are tough to prosecute, particularly when Cuban refugees are
involved. Justice Department data shows that federal prosecutors
historically haven't taken on many alien smuggling cases. A couple
reasons. The smugglees make lousy witnesses. There's also the
built-in defense: ``I'm not a smuggler. I was fishing and rescued
these Cubans from their sinking raft.'' Prosecutors also have felt
that juries of Cuban exiles and other immigrants find it hard to
convict someone of helping their fellow countrymen escape
oppression. Furthermore, the courts haven't been very tough on
convicted smugglers, even if the case involves the deaths of
refugees. For example: In South Fla, the USAtty prosecuted 62
percent of cases referred by the Border Patrol; in Arizona, 92
percent; in Southern California, 99 percent; in South Texas, 99
percent. In South Fla, 26 percent of smuggling cases referred to
USAtty ended with prison sentences; in Arizona, it's 40 percent;
Southern California, 57 percent; South Texas, 58 percent. 60
inches. (Kane, Palm Beach Post)

   SMUGGLE-CASES _ Seven case studies. (Kane, Palm Beach Post)

   FOR MONDAY (Moved today):

   SMUGGLE-WORKSITE _ WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ It's unlawful to hire
non-citizens. But Florida is still the land of opportunity. An
estimated 350,000 illegal aliens reside here. Most work in the
vegetable and citrus farms. Many keep the tourism industry booming
as waiters, hotel maids, etc. Some work on landscaping and
construction crews. But the INS cannot go into the agricultural
fields and doesn't have the manpower to do much other worksite
enforcement because it has to focus attention on alien smuggling.
Farmers hire scores of illegal workers and escape liability by
paying licensed farm labor contractors provide crews. They also
argue that workers today carry counterfeit documents. The INS says
they don't expect growers to be document experts. Migrant worker
advocates argue that farmers use their political clout to handcuff
the INS. For example: in 1990, the INS sanctioned 38 employers in
Florida for hiring illegals. That dropped to 16 in 1991, 6 in 1992
and 2 in 1993. In 1994, 1995 and 1996, it was a dozen or fewer.
Only in 1997 did it get back up to about 20-25 employers.
(Kane/Holland, Palm Beach Post). 60.

   EDS: A CoxNet Focus page featuring the following stories is now
available. See end of budget on how to receive the layout. The
stories have all MOVED.

   ENVIRONMENT-FARMERS _ WACO, Texas _ It is not only big
developers that resent the extremely popular environmental
movement. Farmers are becoming increasingly angry about it. Farmers
across the country are at odds with environmentalists over several
issues, including the disposal of animal waste and the banning of
widely-used pesticides. (Moscoso, Cox News Service).

   WITH

   ENVIRONMENT-GORE _ WASHINGTON _ The conflict between farmers and
environmental groups has put Vice President Al Gore into a bit of a
pickle. Known and praised as an environmentalist, Gore is starting
to realize it is not politically wise to antagonize farmers.
(Moscoso, Cox News Service).

   ENVIRONMENT-WEB _ WASHINGTON _ Environmentalists are
increasingly using the Internet to support their causes. (Moscoso,
Cox News Service).

   WEB-ADDRESSES - List of relevant web sites. (Moscoso, Cox News
Service).

   EDs: Stories moved Wednesday.

   GORE-POLLS _ WASHINGTON _ If Vice President Al Gore is such a
political juggernaut that hardly any Democrat is willing to
challenge him for the party's presidential nomination, why do
opinion polls show him consistently beaten in trial matchups with
potential Republican opponents? (Shepard, Cox News Service).

   MOVED Friday in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   AOL _ FAIRFAX, Va. _ A corporate profile of America Online Inc.,
which is bidding to become a dominant force in providing expanding
online services to a burgeoning consumer market. (Regan, Cox News
Service).

   MOVED Wednesday in (w) Washington and (f) financial categories.

   With AOL-DATA _ Graphics material.

   WITH PHOTOS.

   CABLE-RATES _ WASHINGTON _ Price controls on most cable TV rates
expire March 31. People are already upset that rates have been
climbing at several times inflation over the past few years, even
as satellite and other services have failed to provide significant
competition. What's likely to happen when regulation ends? (Regan,
Cox News Service).

   MOVED Friday in (w) Washington and (f) financial categories.

   WITH

   CABLE-DATA _ Data on biggest cable operators; information on
rates; box on what is being unregulated and what is not.
